text:
In this video, you'll see 
how to integrate software
from AWS Marketplace into EC2 Image Builder.

With this capability, you can 
discover and deploy third-party

software components directly 
within the EC2 Image Builder,

reduce time-to-market for infrastructure 
deployments with automated software updates,

and enhance security and compliance 
by leveraging trusted partner solutions
in EC2 Image Builder.
This is the home page of the AWS console.

To begin, let's navigate to our 
EC2 Image Builder console.

From here, we can discover 
products in AWS Marketplace

that we can subscribe to and use 
in our infrastructure deployments.

Here we can view all of the 
AWS Marketplace third-party
image offerings and their related components.
Let’s look at the Components tab.

Components are modular 
configurations that can

be used to create and maintain 
Amazon Machine Images (or AMI).

Each component defines a set of tasks to be 
performed during the image creation process.

We can search for our desired 
component using various filters.

Let’s view this component’s 
subscription details.

We can see the instances that 
are supported by this component.

After reviewing the details and legal 
terms, we can subscribe to the component.

Now that we’re subscribed, we can 
use the component in an image recipe.

The image recipe will define the 
components to be applied to our base image.

First, we’ll give our recipe 
a name and version number.

The version number becomes important if 
we have to change components in the future,
since image recipes can't be modified.

Next, we’ll choose the 
image to use for this recipe.

We’ll retain the default selection to use the 
latest operating system version available.

This will keep infrastructure 
deployments up-to-date with
automatic version and security updates.

Let's continue down the page, keeping 
other fields at their default value.

Here, we'll specify the build 
components to use with our image recipe.

These can be components we’ve 
built or that we have access to.

For this example, we’ll add the component 
we just subscribed to on AWS Marketplace.

We can add additional components 
to the recipe, if needed.

In this case, we’ll continue on, keeping the 
remaining values as-is, and create the recipe.

Now that we've created the recipe, 
we’ll create an image pipeline for it.

We’ll give the pipeline a name 
and then select a build schedule.

For our purposes, we’ll select the 
option to run the pipeline manually.
Next, we’ll specify our recipe.
Let's scroll down and continue on.

Review the details and 
proceed to the next step.

Next, we'll define the 
infrastructure configuration.

For this example, let's create a 
new infrastructure configuration.
First, we'll provide a name.

Next, we'll select an IAM role that 
contains the necessary permissions

for the instances launched 
by EC2 Image Builder.

Under AWS infrastructure, we'll 
select the instance types that

are supported by the 
component we subscribed to.

These instances can then be used 
to build and test the pipelines.

For the remainder of this pipeline creation 
process, let's use the default values.

Now we'll quickly review the 
details and create the pipeline.
Now that the pipeline has been created,

we can run it to begin creating 
the Amazon Machine Image (AMI).

We can track the creation of this 
image by clicking the log stream link.

You've just seen how to integrate software 
from AWS Marketplace into EC2 Image Builder.

You can learn more about this topic in
the description and links for this video.
Thanks for watching. Now it’s your turn to try.
